title: Poets Offer a Soulful, Spirited Start to the New Year
summary: St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery hosts Poetry Project's annual 10-hour marathon reading in the East Village. Poetry is often considered the least commercial of art forms, one that appeals to a small circle of enthusiasts. A typical poetry reading attracts an audience of a few dozen.

title: Austrian Conservatives and Greens Form Coalition Government
summary: Center-right pushing economic reform and hard line on immigration partners with ecologically driven party. Austria's Conservatives and Greens have agreed to form a new government in a move that could inspire similar alliances across Europe, where incumbent center-right parties are looking to harness rising voter interest in the environment to fight off insurgencies led by populist rivals.

title: Bull Market Is Charging Into 2020
summary: Stocks produced their best gains in years for investors in 2019, both in the U.S. and abroad. Stocks around the world closed out one of their best years over the past decade, defying money managers who began 2019 expecting the bull market to be upended by threats from the U.S.-China trade fight and a slowdown in growth.

title: Hospitals Merged. Quality Didn't Improve.
summary: The quality of care at hospitals acquired during a recent wave of deal making got worse or stayed the same, new research found. The quality of care at hospitals acquired during a recent wave of deal making got worse or stayed the same, new research found, a blow to a frequently cited rationale for tie-ups.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Demand New Year's Resolution
summary: Hundreds of thousands send message that they won't back down until their demands are met. HONG KONG-Hundreds of thousands of protesters began the new year on the streets here, sending a message to authorities that they wouldn't back down until their demands were met, even as Wednesday's demonstration ended with hundreds of arrests and scuffles with police.

title: Protesters Retreat From U.S. Embassy Site in Iraq
summary: Backers of Iran-backed militias withdrew from compound on orders from leadership as push for departure of U.S. troops continues. BAGHDAD-An attempt by supporters of Iran-backed militias to storm the U.S. Embassy here ended on Wednesday, as protesters withdrew from the area after their leadership ordered the suspension of a violent challenge to American troop presence in Iraq.

title: David Stern, Former NBA Commissioner, Dies
summary: During 30 years in charge, Stern transformed the National Basketball Association and championed the sport's globalization. David Stern, who transformed the National Basketball Association and championed the globalization of the sport in his 30 years as the league's commissioner, died Wednesday. He was 77.

title: 'Sonny' Mehta, Editor in Chief of Book Publisher Knopf, Dies
summary: One of New York's most successful publishing executives for three decades, his career was distinguished by keen literary sensibilities and strong commercial instincts, say colleagues. Ajai Singh "Sonny" Mehta, the fabled editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf who published such Nobel Prize-winning authors as Kazuo Ishiguro and Toni Morrison, died Monday, according to a spokesman for Knopf.

title: This Stock Exchange Only Trades on Mondays
summary: Resume Subscription. GEORGETOWN, Guyana-Every Monday at 10 a.m., George Edwards rings the opening bell at the Guyana stock market. It's the only day of action each week, behind a glass door that barely keeps out the thumping bass of reggae music and burning incense from street hawkers outside.

title: Buttigieg Campaign Raised $24.7 Million in Fourth Quarter
summary: With about $76 million in total last year, the former South Bend, Ind., mayor was one of the best fundraisers in the Democratic presidential field. Pete Buttigieg raised $24.7 million in the final three months of the year, his campaign said Wednesday.

title: Netanyahu Seeks Immunity From Israeli Corruption Charges
summary: Request to parliament leaves prime minister's fate riding on March election. TEL AVIV-Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked lawmakers to grant him immunity from prosecution on corruption charges, ahead of an election in March that will decide his personal and political future.

title: FDA to Ban All E-Cigarette Pod Flavors Except Tobacco and Menthol
summary: Impact on small businesses and Trump's re-election prospects drive compromise. The Food and Drug Administration plans to ban the sale of fruity flavors in cartridge-based e-cigarettes, but the restriction won't apply to tank vaping systems commonly found at vape shops, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: In California, New Year Brings New Regulations for Businesses
summary: Laws on privacy, classifying independent contractors took effect on first day of the year. California ushered in a host of laws Wednesday-the first day of the year-that will mean major changes for consumers, workers and businesses.

title: 'The Longing for Less' Review: Upscale Austerity
summary: What is the appeal of today's minimalist aesthetic, as embodied by Marie Kondo, and what does it have to do with Minimalism?. Americans are drowning in stuff. While U.S. houses have more than doubled in size over the past 50 years, 25% of people with two-car garages don't have room enough in them to park their vehicles. It's no wonder the tidying-up maven Marie Kondo has won legions of devotees, all anxious to purge their clutter.

title: North Korean Leader's Warning Signals Tougher Diplomatic Slog
summary: Kim Jong Un threatens a return to provocative tests, in potential setback to disarmament. SEOUL-North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's threat of a return to nuclear and intercontinental ballistic missile tests dials up pressure on the U.S., as President Trump faces the prospect of an election-year setback to what he champions as a signature foreign-policy achievement.

title: Why Would Elizabeth Warren Want More Banks?
summary: Her reform aims to avoid 'too big to fail' but would produce many institutions 'too small to survive.'. America is losing too many banks, according to Sen. Elizabeth Warren. She and Rep. Jesús "Chuy" García (D., Ill.) observe that the number of banks in the U.S. has declined "from over 12,000 in 1990 to less than 5,000 today." This is a problem, they argue, because mergers could create a "new 'Too Big to Fail' bank that could threaten our financial stability." To prevent that, they propose the Bank Merger Review Modernization Act. It's a misguided measure.

title: 'Hate Crime' Is Only a Step Away From Thoughtcrime
summary: Punishing people, even criminals, for ideas is inimical to the American tradition of free speech.. Does it make sense that a person can burn an American flag with impunity but not a gay-pride flag? Earlier this month, a judge in Story County, Iowa, sentenced Adolfo Martinez to a preposterous 16 years in prison for swiping the rainbow flag from a nearby church and burning it in front of a strip club.

title: Latin America's 'Oasis' Descends Into Chaos
summary: What happened to Chile? Its elites lost confidence in the principles that underlay its success.. Chile-Latin America's freest, most stable and richest nation-is in free fall. Public order has collapsed, violence is rampant, and populism is the new creed of the political class. There is a recession, characterized by capital flight and rising unemployment. Income inequality could increase to levels not seen since the 1990s, according to a recent statement by Chile's Central Bank.

title: Google AI Beats Doctors at Breast Cancer Detection-Sometimes
summary: Company has developed similar AI systems for lung cancer, eye disease and kidney injury. Google's health research unit said it has developed an artificial-intelligence system that can match or outperform radiologists at detecting breast cancer, according to new research. But doctors still beat the machines in some cases.

title: Luxury Developers Turn the Page on Old Newspaper Headquarters
summary: What was once the Chicago Tribune's office will now become 162 luxury condos, selling between $900,000 and $7.6 million.. The well-documented decline of the newspaper industry, combined with the enduring popularity of city living, is having one unexpected consequence: reinvention of the urban areas these old media companies once inhabited.

title: Can Tesla Hold Its Charge?
summary: Elon Musk's electric car company might report record quarterly deliveries Thursday, but a look under the hood is less pleasing. Tesla Inc. ended 2019 with a near-record valuation thanks to a nearly 70% rally in the stock price since late October. But investors should be careful not to confuse a buoyant stock price with a sustainably profitable business.

title: Bankruptcy Court Rules Against PG&E Bondholders in Interest-Rate Fight
summary: Judge's decision expected to reduce the company's interest burden by about $550 million. A California bankruptcy court has sided with electric utility PG&E Corp. in its fight with bondholders over the interest rate that it must pay on its debts while under bankruptcy court protection.

title: Work & Family Mailbox: Sue Shellenbarger Answers Readers' Questions
summary: What to do if you've quit a job too hastily, how to get a résumé past the robots, and rules on family leave. Q: I recently quit my job in the heat of the moment, after one of my supervisors laid on me 100% of the blame for a problem he also helped cause. Now I'm having second thoughts. Any advice? -S.L.

title: Jobs and Inflation: The Great Trade-Off, Demystified
summary: The relationship between inflation and unemployment is real, but far from simple. When unemployment goes down, inflation picks up, and when unemployment goes up, inflation cools down. That has been a central tenet of economics for the past 60 years, guiding Federal Reserve policy makers and private forecasters.

title: Surging Amtrak Seeks Congress's Green Light
summary: Railroad saw its best financial year ever but still faces lawmakers skeptical of its profitability-focused strategy. For a company coming off its best year ever, Amtrak faces a strange challenge in 2020: convincing its owner, the federal government, that the railroad is running in the right direction.

title: The Songs Top Artists Had on Repeat in 2019
summary: Resume Subscription. What are the songs that defined the past year?

title: John Steinbeck's Love Letters, Treasures Stashed in Storage Finally Get Unpacked
summary: Resume Subscription. A bunch of old boxes left in storage for years in New York City have yielded a trove of love notes, photos and oddities from the life of John Steinbeck, the Nobel Prize-winning author who died more than 50 years ago.

title: Gertrude Himmelfarb
summary: A scholar who challenged conventions about the Victorians.. She was an accomplished historian known for rigorous scholarship, brilliant essays, and her forceful defense of morality in democratic politics. We're referring to Gertrude Himmelfarb, who died Monday at age 97.

title: Trump's Tumultuous Year, From Policy Wins to Impeachment
summary: Resume Subscription. President Trump ended 2019 with a strong economy, a string of domestic policy achievements-and the notoriety of becoming the third president to be impeached by the House.

title: Chuck Peddle's $25 Microprocessor Ignited Computer Market
summary: Engineer led team whose cheap device, launched in 1975, made desktop machines affordable.

title: Photos: Fire, Smoke and Havoc as Iraqis Rise Up Against U.S.
summary: Iraqi militias and other protesters attack the outside of U.S. Embassy compound in Baghdad in retaliation for U.S. airstrikes that killed 27 militia members near the Iraq-Syria border. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Revelers Around the World Ring In 2020
summary: From Beijing to Rio to Paris, celebrations welcome the new decade. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: English Soccer Can't Stop Talking About Armpits
summary: Instant replay is taking Premier League refs to new levels of nitpicking-and no one is happy. LONDON-In its long-running obsession with individual body parts, English soccer tends to settle on bits like Jamie Vardy's weaponized left foot or Virgil van Dijk's magnetic forehead. But right now the Premier League can't stop talking about armpits.

title: Energy Producers Must Pay the Tab for Shale Drilling Bonanza
summary: North American oil-and-gas companies have more than $200 billion of debt maturing over the next four years. The bill is coming due for the shale industry's price war with OPEC.

title: 2020 Vision: New Year, New Music
summary: These recent singles may foreshadow the directions in which artists will be heading on albums in the coming months..

title: China's Monetary Policy Eases Into the New Year
summary: PBOC to cut amount of reserves commercial banks are required to set aside by half a percentage point, freeing up $115 billion for lending. BEIJING-Chinese officials kicked off the new year-one that is expected to present new challenges for the world's second-largest economy-by signaling a tilt toward easier money.

title: 'We Were Freaking Out.' Fire Season Death Toll Rises in Australia.
summary: Thousands were trapped in an isolated town; blazes out of control across the country. SYDNEY-About 4,000 people trapped by raging wildfires in an isolated holiday town took shelter on the shore and in boats, with the sky turning red and raining embers, as an already devastating fire season took a turn for the worse in Australia.

title: What to Know Before Resolving to Eat Less Meat
summary: As popular campaigns like 'Veganuary' fuel New Year's pledges to cut back on meat, nutrition studies show conflicting findings about the health benefits. Becky Talbot has pledged to go vegan for a month, joining almost 30,000 people across the U.S. who signed up for Veganuary, a campaign encouraging people to do without meat in January.

title: Lessons From Japan's 'Lost Decades'
summary: A record-long U.S. bull market hasn't stopped investors from asking: Is Japanification coming this way, too?. This article is part of the Journal's quarterly markets review.

title: Trump Vows Retaliation After Iran-Backed Militia Supporters Try to Storm U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
summary: Attempt to attack compound underscores U.S. challenge in maintaining forces in Iraq. BAGHDAD-Supporters of an Iran-backed militia tried to storm the American embassy compound in the Iraqi capital, driving the U.S. to send military reinforcements and pointing to the fraught challenge for Washington in maintaining forces in Iraq.

title: The Iranians Escalate in Baghdad
summary: The U.S. will have to deter Tehran's terrorism without alienating Iraq.. As an Iranian proxy militia surrounded and broke into the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad on Tuesday, most of the media framed the incident as a backlash against U.S. military strikes inside Iraq this weekend. The real story is Tehran's desire to push the U.S. out of Iraq-and its effort to coax President Trump to go along.
